holdings.text: Clause 3 of Ordinance No. XIX of 1946 continues all requisitioned lands subject to requisition on 30th September 1946 until expiry of the Ordinance, regardless of any limited duration in the requisition order.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain and grammatical construction of these provisions it was obvious that once you had an immovable property which when the Defence of India Act expired,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain grammatical construction of clause 3 and definition in clause 2 covers all properties subject to requisition on expiry date irrespective of order terms; test is status on 30 Sep 1946.

holdings.text: The non obstante clause does not cut down the clear and unambiguous terms of the operative enactment; it serves as clarification by abundant caution.

anchor.surface_text: although ordinarily there should be a close approximation between the non obstante clause and the operative part of the section, the non obstante clause need not necessarily and always be coextensive with the operative part

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of enactment clear on plain construction; non obstante need not be co-extensive and cannot restrict scope where interpretation unambiguous.

holdings.text: Provisions affecting liberty and property rights are strictly construed, but such construction cannot override the clear and express words of the statute.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt measures which affect the liberty of the subject and his rights to property have got to be strictly construed. But in spite of such strict construction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges strict construction principle but holds it yields to plain terms covering all requisitions on expiry date, even limited ones.

holdings.text: Courts must give effect to valid legislative measures affecting individual cases and cannot consider equities unless mala fides or abuse of power is alleged.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Once measure lawfully enacted and covers case, courts bound despite prejudice to owners; intervention only on mala fides grounds.

holdings.text: Both trial court and Court of Appeal erred in holding that clause 3 did not continue the requisitioning order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects lower courts' narrow construction limiting clause 3 to orders expiring solely due to Act's end; affirms broad textual scope.

holdings.text: Matter remanded to Court of Appeal for decision on all points raised in trial court, not just the short point on clause 3.

anchor.surface_text: we cannot help remanding the matter to the Court of appeal with a direction that the appeal be disposed of on all the points which were dealt with by the trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court lacks benefit of appellate judgment on other points; necessary for full disposal despite sympathy for respondent.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court erred in holding that clause 3 of Ordinance No. XIX of 1946 did not continue the requisition order; matter remanded to High Court for consideration of all points decided by trial court.
directions: remanding the matter to the Court of appeal with a direction that the appeal be disposed of on all the points which were dealt with by the trial Court
